ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: After studying my topic for a full year, I feel like I have the knowledge to genuinely contribute to my area of study. I have gained confidence in my research and writing that I did not have before.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Collin was our only point of communication and he was great!

The EP&E department, in general, is not a very supportive department. Besides Kelli, none of the faculty have been in EP&E as long as thesis-ing seniors have. The graduate student advisors are a nice addition, but really, our actual academic advisor (the DUS) should be way more involved. EP&E is not a political economy department. Other EP&E students and I don't feel surrounded by faculty and grad students who are truly excited about interdisciplinary study. When I applied to EP&E, it was marketed as a small, supportive, and close-knit intellectual community. I met EP&E students in my year for the first time at Collin's office hours during the last week of the course, where he brought students together over coffee and grocery store cookies.  I am confident EP&E has the money to invest in facilitating relationships among students and truly getting to know each student intellectually.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you're interested in going into research in the future, a full-year thesis is certainly the way to go. The EP&E department does a good job being pretty hands off and letting you pursue your research alone.

My thesis advisor was excellent and I am passionate about my topic, but writing a year-long 100-page thesis is exhausting. Nothing can really make it not exhausting. I'm glad I did it, but I am not eager to tell my peers to jump at the opportunity to write a year-long EP&E thesis. I generally encourage people not to major in EP&E at this point, unless their primary interests are political theory or political economy.
